STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 2, 2023
Annetra Bennett
Samaritas - Southeast
8131 E. Jefferson Ave
Detroit, MI 48214-2610
RE: License#: CB630201265
Investigation# 2023C0000054
Dear Ms. Bennett:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at (734) 395-4347.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
brownp2@michigan.gov
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
cc: Laura Mitchell

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201265
Investigation #: 2023C0000054
Complaint Receipt Date: 11/22/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 11/23/2022
Report Due Date: 12/23/2022
Name: Samaritas - Southeast
Address: 2170 E. Big Beaver, Ste B
Troy, MI. 48083
Telephone #: 989 – 832 -3432
Administrator: Annetra Bennett
Licensee Designee: Ann Meldrum
Name of Facility: SAMARITAS - SOUTHEAST
Facility Address: 8131 E JEFFERSON AVE
DETROIT, MI 48214-2610
Facility Telephone #: (248)423 -2760
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
License Status: Regular
Effective Date: 11/22/2022
Expiration Date: 12/23/2022
Capacity:
Program Type: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSURE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
CONTRACT – TRETMENT FOSTER CARE
CONTRACT – SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT
LIVING
4

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established
Foster care agency moved foster youth from a licensed home with their No
sibling who they had a history of inappropriate sexual relation with. This
placement appears contrary to the physical, emotional and safety needs
of both youths.
CPA 400. 12405 Change of Placement
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s record
before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new placement,
consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS Violation
Established
Youth was placed in Licensed placement on 11/3/2022 and was not Yes
enrolled in school until 11/21/2022, exceeding 5 days expectation.
CPA Rule 400.12409 Education
(1) An agency’s education policy shall ensure that within 5 school
days of placement, an agency shall provide for the enrollment of
each child of school age, as defined by state law, into a school
program.
Foster care agency moved foster youth from a licensed home with their Yes
sibling who they had a history of inappropriate sexual relation with.
DHHS FOM 722-03F – Approved Absences from Foster Care Placement
– Absences for six or 14 days.
Foster Care supervisor approval is required for the absence and must be
documented in a caseworker contact.
The placement must be considerate intact by the caregiver and returned
to the placement is planned.
The caregiver agrees to remain involved with the child and/or the child’s
family during the absence.
Payments may be continue as long as the payment is maintained for the
child and a return to the placement is planned.
Do not change the child’s placement in MiSACWIS.
4

III. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Type Contact Method Contact Purpose
11/22/2022 Special Investigation Email Other
Intake 2023C0000054
11/23/2022 Interview Face-to-face Interview with Chief
Administrator and program
manager and caseworker.
11/23/2022 Interview Telephone Caseworker of Youth A and
the Director of Foster Care
and Adoption of Youth B’s
placement.
12/14/2022 MiSACWIS Document review Review of Youth A’s
documentation, updated
service plans, court report,
TDM, safety plan.
12/15/2022 CPA Contact Face to Face Preliminary Exit Conference
IV. INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CPA 400. 12405 Change of Placement
Section (3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s record
Description before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new placement,
consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care agency moved foster youth from a licensed home with their
sibling who they had a history of inappropriate sexual relation with. This
placement appears contrary to the physical, emotional and safety needs
of both youths.
Investigation The Reporting Source was not interviewed for this investigation because
a telephone number or contact information was not provided for an
interview.
Youth A’s Caregiver (Foster Parent 1) was not interviewed for this
investigation. Several Messages were left for Youth A’s Foster Parent to
contact this Consultant; however, no return calls were received.
Program Manager was interviewed face to-face 11/23/2022. She
reported that Youth A was placed with their agency foster parent on
07/30/2021. She reported that Youth A’s older sibling contacted Youth A
over the weekend of October 8th and ask him could he babysit her child.
4

She reported Youth A wanted to babysit and that Youth A’s Foster Parent
(Foster Parent 1) wanted to discuss with him babysitting his sister’s
young child. She reported that after discussing this issue with Youth A,
Youth A became enraged and destroyed items in his bedroom. The
Program Manager reported that Foster Parent 1 did not feel safe with
Youth A in her home anymore and she arranged for Youth A’s sister’s
Foster Parent (Foster Parent 2) to take Youth A into her home for respite
care. The Program Manager said the Foster Parents of both agencies
decided to make this decision on their own without following policies of
both agencies to notify caseworkers from Samaritas – Southeast and
Child Safe agencies.
The Program Manager reported when she learned of this information on
Monday, 10/10/2022 from Foster Parent 1 due to her stating she did not
want Youth A back into her home, she immediately reached out to Child
Safe and DHHS to discuss case planning for Youth A on 10/11/2022. She
said during this time, due to Youth A being in the home of Foster Parent
2, and he was familiar with being in Foster Parent 2’s home, it was
decided to arrange for him to remain with Foster Parent 2 as emergency
respite until another placement was found for Youth A. This decision was
based on Foster Parent 1 not wanting Youth A to return to her home and
Youth A’s refusal to return to the home of Foster Parent 1. She said a
Team Decision Meeting (TDM) was held on 10/18/2022, regarding
placement of Youth A. The Program Manager stated that Child Safe and
DHHS were not in agreement of Youth A staying in the foster home of
Foster Parent 2. She said a decision was made to seek another foster
home utilizing a borrowed bed. The Program Manager reported that due
to Foster Parent 2’s home being the home of Youth A’s sister, a safety
plan was created for the home and signed for the safety of both youths.
This plan was immediately shared with Foster Parent 2.
Program Manager reported another meeting was held with Child Safe
and DHHS regarding Youth A’s placement on 10/25/2022. She said due
to Child Safe and DHHS not agreeing with the placement of Youth A in
Foster Parent 2’s home, a 4606 form was completed. This form is a
placement assistance request form that is completed any time the agency
is looking for a new placement for a youth. She reported this form lists all
the efforts to obtain the most appropriate placement for a child per the
rule (4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in selecting
an appropriate placement for a child: (a) The permanency goal for the
child. (b) The physical, emotional, and educational needs of the child. The
Program Manager reported an analysis of whether or not the placement
did or did not meet the youth needs were completed and this form was
shared in the TDM held on 11/30/2022.
4

The Director of Child Safe was interviewed VIA telephone call. She
explained that her agency did not agree with the placement of Youth A in
their foster home in the beginning. She said her agency learned that
Youth A had gone to their foster home, (Foster Parent 2) on an
emergency basis from her Licensing Supervisor on 10/11/2022. She said
she did not believe it was a good fit because her agency did not think
Foster Parent 2 could handle supervising the youth one hundred percent.
She said the sexual allegation between the siblings was thoroughly
discussed among the agencies and DHHS and although the sexual
interaction was not substantiated, safety measures were still taken when
the youth visited each other. The Director said Youth A and Youth B
were to be supervised at all times and that overnight visits between the
youths were no longer taking place as a precaution when Youth A visited
the home of Foster Parent 2. She said when the FTM occurred on
10/18/2022 to discuss Youth A’s placement, Child Safe continued to
express that long-term placement was not likely feasible. The Director
said at that time DHHS agreed with Child Safe and that Samaritas was to
continue to search for an alternate placement.
The Director of Child Safe reported on 10/24/22, Foster Parent 2
expressed to the Child Safe foster care worker that she may be willing to
keep Youth A on a permanent basis. Foster Parent 2 agreed that the
youths would be supervised at all times. The Director reported another
FTM specifically for Youth A was held on 11/17/22, in which DHHS
expressed that this may not be the best placement and wanted Samaritas
to continue to search for another home.
The Program Manager and Program Director of Samaritas and Child
Safe reported a FTM was held on 11/30/22 to discuss both youth’s
placements. Both youths participated in this FTM. DHHS worker and
supervisor were also present. Youth A and B advocated for themselves
and were very well-spoken. The sexual allegations were discussed with
the youth’s and they both agreed that they would not have a problem with
being supervised at all times. The agencies agreed to put additional
supports in place for Foster Parent 2 and a detailed updated safety plan
would be completed. In addition, the agency provided Foster Parent 2
with door alarms so that she knows when a bedroom door opens or
shuts. The Program Director of Child Safe reported there have been
absolutely no concerns of any inappropriate sexual behaviors between
the two youths since these allegations were reported. Both agencies and
DHHS agreed that as long as safety measures are taken and the safety
plan is reviewed every three months, placement could continue. DHHS
also agreed to the placement. Numerous safety plans were reviewed and
completed during the time Youth A started his placement at Foster Parent
2’s home.
4

The Program Manager reported that Youth B’s foster parent through
Child Safe decided to maintain placement of Youth A and all parties
agreed that the placement was appropriate with the safety plans
previously set in place. The Program Manager said additional placement
assistance was not requested through the Regional Placement Unit. She
said discussions regarding the previous sexual acting out behaviors
between Youth A and Youth B were held during the meetings and all
parties concurred that there had not been any concerns regarding this
type of behavior between the siblings since they were brought into
care. The siblings had frequent, and regular visitation facilitated between
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 and no concerns were noted. The
Program Manager said it was assessed with the safety plans in place
whereby Foster Parent 2, Youth A and Youth B agreed to the safety plan.
She said Foster Parent 2 agreed to maintain placement of Youth A and
this was in the youth’s best interest to be placed together. She said this
also allowed for sibling reunification.
The Program Director of Child Safe said that Foster Parent 2 is very
experienced and capable of handling difficult youth and has taken the
steps necessary to make sure that both youths are safe. She said she is
in agreement with the placement.
Documentation reviewed:
• Safety Plans for Youth A and Youth B.
• Youth A’s Service plans in MiSACWIS discussing his history and
behaviors while in care.
Analysis The allegations of sexual behavior were never substantiated and there
was never any inappropriateness between Youth A and Youth B. Both
Youth A and Youth B as well as Foster Parent 2 agreed to the safety
plan. Foster Parent 2 is very experienced and capable of handling difficult
youth and has taken steps necessary to make sure that both youths are
safe. Samaratis – Southeast shared the 4606 form with all parties
participating in the TDM held on 11/30/2022 regarding Youth A’s
permanency goal and the physical, emotional, and educational needs of
Youth A. It was at this meeting that all parties agreed that this is the best
placement for Youth A.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
4

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12409 Education
Section (1) An agency’s education policy shall ensure that within 5 school
Description days of placement, an agency shall provide for the enrollment of
each child of school age, as defined by state law, into a school
program.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was placed in Licensed placement on 11/3/2022 and was not
enrolled in school until 11/21/2022, exceeding 5 days expectation.
Investigation During the investigation, it was determined that due to Youth A refusing
to return to his foster care placement where he was attending school
and the foster care provider refusing to allow Youth A back into her
home, Youth A was not attending school due to the distance of his
current location. Youth A left his school district on 10/8/2022 and was
not enrolled into current school district until 11/21/2022.
Program Manager reported Youth A stopped attending his school on
10/08/2022 when he had the altercation with his Foster Parent 1 and
moved to the home of Foster Parent 2. She said her agency was unable
to get Youth A’s school to provide him with virtual learning and because
he was only supposed to be temporarily staying with Foster Parent 2,
Foster Parent 2 was unable to enroll Youth A elsewhere. The Program
Manager reported that Youth A and his sister are in the same grade and
his sister brought Youth A’s her assigned schoolwork home so he could
stay current with classes. The Program Manager said Youth A was
officially enrolled in his new school on 11/21/22 when Youth A’s
placement was made official.
Analysis Youth A was attending school regularly when placed with his foster
parent with Samaritas - Southeast however, when his placement was
interrupted and he moved to another placement, he was unable to be
enrolled into a different school district. Youth A was not attending or
enrolled in school from 10/8/2022 until 11/21/2022. The agency is in
violation with this rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4

Rule Code & DHHS FOM 722-03F – Approved Absences from Foster Care
Section Placement – Absences for six or 14 days.
Description Foster Care supervisor approval is required for the absence and must
be documented in a caseworker contact.
The placement must be considerate intact by the caregiver and returned
to the placement is planned.
The caregiver agrees to remain involved with the child and/or the child’s
family during the absence.
Payments may be continue as long as the payment is maintained for the
child and a return to the placement is planned.
Do not change the child’s placement in MiSACWIS.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation DHHS did not provide their approval of Youth A’s continued placement
with his sister until 51 days after he left his assigned foster home. There
was no documentation to indicate that approval was provided for the
absence of Youth A from his previous foster home.
Investigation The Program Manager explained that Youth A’s foster parent and
Youth A’s sister’s foster parent from another agency arrange sibling
visits between Youth A and his sister, Youth B occurring at least every
other Saturday. This arrangement was also a respite placement for
Youth A.
It is noted that Samaritas – Southeast has full responsibility for Youth A.
Child Safe has full responsibility for Youth A’s Sister (Youth B).
Foster Care Caseworker was interviewed on 11/23/2022, face to
face. She reported that Youth A was placed with another agency foster
parent as a temporary emergency placement until 11/03/2022. She
reported that Foster Parent 2 placement of Youth A became a borrowed
bed on 11/03/2022. She said all paperwork was signed between
agencies allowing Youth A to live with his sister (Youth B) in the home of
Foster Parent 2.
The Caseworker reported a TDM was held on 10/18/2022 to discuss
Youth A’s placement. She reported that Youth B’s foster care case
manager and licensing supervisor expressed that they did not think that
Youth A being placed in the home of (Foster Parent 2) long-term was a
good idea. DHHS representative was present at this meeting. The
terms of the safety plan were discussed, and Foster Parent 2 was told
that the youths could not be alone together at any time due to the
previous allegations between Youth A and Youth B alleged sexually
acting out behavior although the allegations were not substantiated by
DHHS. The Caseworker reported Youth A and Youth B participated in a
4

KIDS TALK prior to coming into care regarding the allegations of
sexually acting out and the KIDS TALK therapist concluded that the
allegations could not be substantiated. The Caseworker said during this
TDM, Foster Parent 2 said she would be willing to keep Youth A in her
home. Foster Parent 2 had a concerned that she would not be able to
meet the guidelines of the safety plan one day per week when she had a
standing appointment. She said Foster Parent 2 verbally agree to the
safety plan at the time of the TDM. The Caseworker reported at this
TDM, it was also discussed that Samaritas should continue to make
efforts to locate a new placement. Samaritas was going to work with
DHHS to complete a search for Youth A so the case would be referred
to the Regional Placement Unit (RPU) for assistance. Foster care
caseworker was also going to follow up with Foster Parent 2 regarding
her ability and willingness to care for Youth A on a more permanent
basis.
The Caseworker reported another meeting was held on 10/25/2022
because it was confirmed that Youth A was in need of a placement and
that his Foster Parent (1) did not want Youth A to return to her home.
She said the full team agreed that Youth A and Youth B could continue
the current placement with Foster Parent 2 with a detailed safety plan
that included door chimes, and each youth will participate in therapy
along with services provided to Foster Parent 2 to help maintain a
healthy placement for the youths. The Caseworker said a detailed safety
plan was created and agreed upon and that this placement would be
reviewed quarterly to confirm the safety and well-being of Youth A and
Youth B staying together. This decision included a brief conference with
DHHS Section Manager.
Review of MiSACWIS and case documentation updated service plans
on 12/14/2022.
Youth A’s Updated services plans dated 0/09/2022 – 10/04/2022 and
10/05/2022 – 01/02/2023.
These reports discussed Youth A’s move into another foster home
utilizing a borrowed bed placement in the foster home of his sibling.
Parental termination being denied and Youth A’s feelings of not wanting
to return to the care of his biological mother. There was no
documentation observed in the caseworker notes that the agency
received approval as required by FOM 722 – 03F for Youth A to be in
respite over 15 days.
There was documentation that a TDM was held on 10/18/2022. Youth A
had been absent from his placement since 10/08/2022, 10 days.
4

TDM documentation dated 10/18/2022. The report states the
following:
The reason for the TDM was to discuss the change of placement for
Youth A. The team discussed filing a 30 – day notice, respite care,
supportive services, and placement options for Youth A.
Youth A is currently in respite care with his sister. He is described
as a “Kind boy.” He is mild mannered and tempered. Foster Parent
2 is interested in taking placement of Youth A. There is an out of
state relative interested in placement. This option will be explored.
It is recommended that Youth A is moved from his current foster
home and placed in another approved foster care placement.
Placement efforts will continue. All court orders and services should
remain in effect. Youth A is in need of a permanent placement.
Youth A and B’s Safety Plan dated 12/01/2022.
Youth A and Youth B is placed in an unrelated/licensed foster
home with Foster Parent 2. Youth A and Youth B agrees to abide
with Samaritas – Southeast and Child Safe Michigan and follow the
terms of the safety plan outlined below.
Youth A and Youth B’s Safety Plan
• Foster Parent 2 agrees to ensure Youth B and Youth A is
supervised and utilize the safely measures that is currently in
place such as bells on the bedroom doors and leaving
bedroom doors open when they are in the same bedroom.
• Foster Parent 2 agrees to continue to utilize kid lock for Youth
A and Youth B’s electronic devices.
• Foster Parent 2 agrees to ensure when needed appropriate
support person that could assist with supervising the youths
as needed.
• Foster Parent 2 agrees to have separate bedrooms for each
youth.
• Foster Parent 2 agrees to utilize the Emergency Contact #:
313-999-2780 for Child Safe if emergency arises.
• Youth B agrees to actively participate in weekly individual
therapy and be open and honest with the therapist.
• Youth B agrees to participate in Child Safe’s Mentorship
program.
• Youth B agrees and understands she will not go into another
person’s bedroom, she must get permission first.
4

• Youth B agrees and understands if someone is visiting her
bedroom, she must leave the door open.
• Youth B will dress appropriately around the house for example
no sports bra and spandex.
• Youth B understands there should be only one person in the
bathroom at one time.
• Youth B understands she is the only person that is allowed to
sleep in her bed and/or bedroom.
• Youth B understands there is to be no sexual contact or
sexualized behaviors such as letting anyone touch her private
areas on her body.
• Youth B understands if she has questions or wants a better
understanding about sex or her body/development she will
ask Foster Parent 2.
• Youth B agrees there will be no inappropriate sexualized
language such as referencing her personal body parts or
talking about sexual activity with Youth A around.
• Youth B agrees and understand she is responsible for her
behaviors and may have consequences if she does not follow
the rules.
• Youth A agrees to not use the internet and social media for
sexual purposes while on school grounds.
• Youth A agrees to not use the internet and social media for
sexual purposes at any time.
• Youth A agrees that it is not okay to show others his private
areas via social media or solicited phonograph pictures from
others.
This safety plan will be reviewed every 90 days. Next revision is Feb. 2,
2023.
Analysis The agency became aware that Youth A had left his foster care
placement on 10/10/2022 and was living in the home of his sister’s
foster care placement since 10/08/2022. A TDM was not held until
10/18/2022. The agency did not immediately develop a safety plan for
Youth A living in the home knowing that there were allegations of
sexually inappropriate behavior between Youth A and Youth B, although
it was not substantiated by KIDS TALK. DHHS did not provide their
approval of Youth A’s continued placement with his sister until
11/30/2022. There was no documentation to indicate that approval was
provided for the absence of Youth A from his previous foster home in
caseworker contact notes. Therefore, a violation is established.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4

V. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, we recommend that the current license
status be continued.
03/01/2023
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
03/06/2023
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Program Manager
4
